awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Revolutionizing Systematics - Revitalizing Monographs
awd_abstract_narration:
Taxonomic monographs are comprehensive treatments of organismal groups that include descriptions of the appearance of species, estimates of their geographical range, rationale for their delimitation, and details of their genealogical relationships and patterns of diversification. The critical baseline data on biodiversity included in taxonomic monographs can be used by biologists and non-experts alike. While other aspects of systematic biology research have embraced cutting-edge methodologies and analysis pipelines, many monographs are produced and published the same as they have been for decades.  This project will support a series of workshops to engage the systematic biology community and identify strategies to reinvigorate and modernize taxonomic monographs.   Four workshops will identify and incorporate innovations in computing, data visualization, and workflows to provide solutions to systemic and scientific challenges facing monographic research. The workshops will catalyze conversations and build collaborations that will strengthen and broaden the practice of monography. Invitations to participate in the workshops will be posted on the websites of professional societies with systematic biologist members, and participants will be selected with the goal of achieving breadth in expertise, career stage, gender and ethnic diversity.  Products resulting from the workshops will be broadly and freely disseminated via scientific publications and websites.

These workshops aim to realize the potential for taxonomic monographs to become central hubs that link and synthesize biodiversity information, with improved access to detailed phenotypic and geographic data, more dynamic, nuanced, and integrated taxonomies, and fully explicit, accessible, and testable hypotheses about organisms, their attributes, and their diversification. In addition to stimulating interactions among systematists who conduct monographic studies in diverse taxonomic groups and among systematists who work on questions that are or could be integrated into monographs, these workshops will engage the community of database scientists, computational biologist, software developers, and others to find novel solutions to the challenges of data access and integration.  The workshops will culminate in a synthesis and consolidation of the ideas developed in the preceding workshops, aimed at building prototypes of tools, workflows, and structures that can be tested and improved by the broader community of systematic biologists. The technological and conceptual developments that will be integrated into monography will make the data of monographs more accessible and impactful across fields, and the interdisciplinarity that will be fostered by engaging database scientists, computational scientists, and software developers will support long-term and innovative solutions that capitalize on the integrative and comprehensive perspectives of taxonomic monographs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to catalyze discussions among systematic biologists to revitalize taxonomic monographs. Even though taxonomic monographs are the most important and long-lasting output of systematics research, little has changed in the last ca. 200 years in the way these comprehensive documents are assembled, structured, and published. Taxonomic monographs address questions relevant to some of the most research-active areas in systematic biology, including species delimitation, phylogeography, speciation, species trees, and ontology development, as well as test hypotheses of broader interest in evolutionary biology related to the processes that generate species-level diversity. Yet, very few systematic biologists working on these areas engage in monographic work and many trainees are not capable or interested in doing this kind of work. Significant recent technical advances inside and outside of systematic biology present monographs with novel opportunities to engage in cutting edge science and to do it in ways that are integrative, forward-looking, and exciting. We ran three workshops to address challenges and opportunities related to the future of monographic research and its disconnect with current active areas of research in systematics that independently make-up the content of monographs. Our aim was to highlight and build on the intellectual potential of monography by convening meetings that used panel discussions and working groups of scientists across the career spectrum and with diverse taxonomic and technical expertise focusing on three angles. Workshop 1 convened researchers engaged in revisionary systematics to discuss bottlenecks and opportunities in training, practice, and career development that support or limit the production of monographic works. In Workshop 2, we convened a mix of systematists engaged in monography and systematists working at the interface of biodiversity informatics and computer science to identify and apply new technologies to energize, expand, and unify monographic research. Workshop 3 convened a diverse group of researchers, including but not limited to participants in Workshops 1 and 2 to brainstorm new ideas, develop new and bold approaches to address challenges in monographic research, and write manuscripts that addressed the points raised in the workshops. As a result of our workshops, we published five scientific papers as a volume in the new Open Access journal of the Society of Systematic Biologists, called the Bulletin of the Society of Systematic Biologists. These five articles addressed a range of topics, including discussions about the value inherent in published monographs and workflows that can help make those data accessible, discussions on how modern monographs could work as portals of diversity linking data and metadata via Persistent Identifiers, discussions about the socio-academic recognition of monographic work and ways in which researchers engaged in monography could receive support and recognition for their work, and discussions into the recognition of researchers involved in monography and a new framework to evaluate professionals involved in monography and beyond.

This project supported the professional development of three graduate students in taxonomy, revisionary systematics, and scientific publishing. The 51 workshop attendees were diverse in career stage (16 ECR), and demographic background (25 women, 26 men). Women and/or pre-tenure researchers (including one student) lead four of the five manuscripts. Our three workshops established connections between researchers with different expertises, fostered the creation of collaborations, and sowed the seeds for future research proposals aiming to develop the ideas developed in the published articles. The impact of the publications resulting from this project have the potential to reach areas outside of systematic biology. For instance, the publication about credit and recognition of various kinds of professional duties will contribute to a growing discussion about support and equity in academic labor markets. The publications about workflows and accessibility of data have potential applications and benefits for artificial intelligence/machine learning technologies that pull and sort data.
